Investment Program  The Transmission and Distribution Sector Investment Program 
Description  (the Investment Program) includes the following components and 
costs: (i) access to power (transmission) and energy efficiency 
enhancement  (transmission  loss  reduction),  $561.6  million 
(73.5%); (ii) access to power (distribution) and energy efficiency 
enhancement  (distribution  loss  reduction)  and  distribution 
franchising, $150 million (19.6%); (iii) distributed decentralized 
generation, $50 million (6.5%); and (iv) capacity development 
$2.4 million (0.3%). In addition, technical assistance (TA) will 
also be provided. The physical investments will address current 
unserved  energy  demand  and  provide  additional  capacity  to 
meet forecast demand growth. 
 
   
Background   The  Government  of  India  (the  Government),  recognizing 
electricity as one of the key drivers for economic growth and 
poverty reduction, has confirmed its mission to provide electricity 
to all households at an affordable price by 2012.  
 
In 2006 the Government introduced the Integrated Energy Policy 
to ensure adequate and reliable energy supplies in a technically 
efficient,  economically  viable,  and  environmentally  sustainable 
manner.  Specific  measures  of  the  policy  include  continuing 
related power reforms, e.g., reducing aggregated technical and 
commercial  losses  of  the  state  transmission  and  distribution 
(T&D) utilities and other restructuring efforts.  
 
The government of Assam (GOA) set out a policy for power 
reforms in the Power Policy Statement 2003. Aims of the policy 
include (i) achievement of commercial efficiency and financial 
viability of the power sector so that it will not require Assam’s 
financial  resources,  which  are  needed  for  socioeconomic 
development;  (ii)  improved  delivery  of  services  and 
cost-effectiveness  through  technical,  managerial,  and 
administrative  restructuring  of  power  utilities;  and 
(iii) increased operating efficiency of all power utilities through

ii 
 
competition, managerial autonomy, and higher accountability.  
 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) supported Assam’s power 
reforms  through  the  Assam  Power  Sector  Development 
Program. The program comprised a $150 million program loan 
(2036-IND) and a $100 million project loan (2037-IND). In 2002, 
in  tandem  with  the  program,  Assam  State  Electricity  Board 
(ASEB),  under  the  Companies  Act  (1956),  incorporated  its 
successor  entities:  Assam  Power  Generation  Corporation 
Limited  (APGCL);  Assam  Electricity  Grid  Corporation  Limited 
(AEGCL);  and  three  distribution  companies:  Central  Assam 
Electricity  Distribution  Company  Limited  (CAEDCL),  Lower 
Assam Electricity Distribution Company Limited (LAEDCL) and 
Upper  Assam  Electricity  Distribution  Company  Limited 
(UAEDCL). ASEB remains active as a coordinating agency. In 
April 2009, CAEDCL and UAEDCL were merged into LAEDCL to 
enhance operating efficiency. 
 
AEGCL develops, operates, and maintains the transmission grid 
in the state; and LAEDCL develops, operates, and maintains the 
distribution  grid.  Improvements  include  increased  T&D  circuit 
length, increased T&D capacity, and reduced T&D losses (from 
42.5% in 2003 to 35.0% in 2009). Assam's future peak power 
demand is forecasted to increase to 1,883 megawatts (MW) by 
2014 with an annual increase of 14.2%. To meet the demand, 
new power plants will be constructed with sufficient additional 
capacity. However, limited capacity of the Assam T&D system 
can constrain the delivery of power to consumers. Therefore, 
T&D capacity needs to be expanded and system access and 
efficiency enhanced. 
 
  Policy  Environment.  The  Electricity  Act  (2003)  provides  a 
comprehensive  legal  framework  for  implementing  reforms, 
including (i) unbundling state electricity boards, (ii) establishing 
state regulators, (iii) licensing, and (iv) developing an antitheft 
provision. Certain provisions in the act have been initiated, e.g., 
(i) open access to the T&D network, (ii) recognition of power 
trading  as  a  distinct  activity,  (iii)  creation  of  distribution 
franchisees, and (iv) a minimum  procurement requirement by 
licensees from renewable sources. 
 
Road  Map.  GOA  developed  a  T&D  road  map  linked  to  the 
Investment Program. The objective is to establish the route to 
achieve sustainable T&D growth in the state. It aims to deliver 
the  following  outcomes:  (i)  strengthened  power  transmission 
capacity to deliver reliable and affordable electricity, (ii) improved 
access  to  electricity,  (iii)  enhanced  efficiency  and  quality  of 
power supply, (iv) ensured financial health of the power sector 
through continued reform, and (v) mainstreamed private sector 
participation.

iii 
Multitranche Financing  The financing will be provided under a multitranche financing 
Facility  facility  (MFF),  in  accordance  with  ADB  policy.  The  MFF  will 
extend multiple loans not exceeding $200 million, in aggregate, 
to finance part of the costs of projects under the Investment 
Program. The MFF is expected to be provided in three tranches.  
 
The  provisions  of  the  ordinary  operations  loan  regulations 
applicable  to  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate 
(LIBOR)-based loans will apply to each loan. The specific terms 
of  each  loan  will  be  based  on  the  related  periodic  financing 
request (PFR) with interest to be determined in accordance with 
ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility.  The  Government  has 
provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under 
ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility; and (ii) an undertaking that 
these choices were made independently, and did not rely on any 
communication or advice from ADB.  
   
Rationale  The Investment Program will (i) strengthen power transmission 
capacity to deliver reliable and affordable electricity, (ii) improve 
access to electricity in distribution through grid electricity and 
off-grid  renewable  and  conventional  energy-based  electricity, 
(iii) enhance efficiency and quality of power supply, (iv) ensure 
financial health of the power sector through continued reform, 
and  (v)  promote  private  sector  participation.  The  Investment 
Program includes a capacity development program component 
to meet the increasing management capacity requirements.  
 
The MFF is particularly well suited for the Investment Program 
because (i) its aim is to support GOA’s long-term objectives, as 
stated in the T&D road map; (ii) the performance of ongoing 
projects under the MFF can guide the provision of subsequent 
loans, thereby offering proper incentives for implementation; and 
(iii) the MFF can offer the flexibility required for the Investment 
Program to support participation of the utilities at different stages 
of readiness.  
  
Impact and Outcome  The  Investment  Program  is  expected  to  promote  sustainable 
provision of electricity in the state with increased T&D capacity to 
support inclusive economic growth.  
 
The outcome is enhanced quality and expanded service delivery 
of electricity in Assam through improved technical, commercial, 
and financial performance and capability of ASEB and the power 
utilities.  
   
Investment Plan   During the Investment Program from 2009 to 2014, GOA intends 
to  carry  out  T&D  enhancements  valued  at  $764  million  with 
support from the Government, ADB, and other stakeholders.

Before ADB accepts a PFR under the Facility, the Government,

include capacity development.

Retroactive financing is proposed under the individual loans for

corresponding loan agreement, with a ceiling up to 20% of the

MFF Benefits and  Overall the MFF will contribute to state economic development 
Beneficiaries  on several fronts. The first group of beneficiaries will be local 
electricity  consumers,  including  around  1  million  electrified 
households;  small-  and  medium-sized  businesses,  e.g.,  silk 
factories;  hospitals;  and  schools.  The  second  group  of 
beneficiaries includes all existing electricity consumers including 
domestic users (51%), commercial users (10%), industrial users 
(27%),  agricultural  users  (2%),  and  others  (10%).  They  will 
benefit  from  the  enhanced  power  operations.  Through  the 
distribution  franchising  component,  720  entrepreneurs  are 
expected  to  expand  their  operations  with  at  least  1,500  new 
employees.  In  addition,  construction  of  infrastructure  and 
installation of information and communication technologies are 
expected  to  create  at  least  500  jobs.  The  renewable  energy 
development component will provide a benefit for 2,100 villages 
with off-grid renewable energy in the long term. Assam has a 
very  high  incidence  of  poverty.  About  89%  of  the  state’s 
population lives in rural areas, and approximately 60% of rural 
households  are  living  below  the  poverty  line.  The  rural 
electrification component will have a direct benefit for the poor. 
The Investment Program will rationalize tariffs as well as improve 
the financial viability of the state’s power industry. 
   
Technical Assistance  Consistent  with  the  sector  assistance  program  evaluation 
  (SAPE)  recommendations,  ASEB  will  continue  to  receive 
consulting support from a TA (the TA) attached to the investment 
program  for  capacity  development  of  APGCL,  AEGCL,  and 
LAEDCL to enhance general institutional capacity in the areas of 
corporate management, human resource management, financial 
management,  distribution  franchising,  and  renewable  energy

vii 
development. The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.3 million 
equivalent. ADB will provide technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $1.0 million. This will be financed by ADB, on a 
grant basis, from the ADB’s TA funding program TASF-Others. 
The Government will provide the remaining balance equivalent of 
$300,000. ASEB will be the Executing Agency for the TA.  
   
Risks and Assumptions  The key assumption is that GOA will remain committed to the 
Investment Program and the power reforms with the objective of 
providing  power  for  all.  Other  important  assumptions  include 
(i) an adequate number of competent staff is available for ASEB, 
AEGCL, and LAEDCL; (ii) load growth in Assam continues as 
projected;  (iii)  regulatory  mechanisms  and  interventions  are 
consistent; and (iv) the TA is successfully implemented.   
 
Risks include (i) an increase in the price of materials, and (ii) 
failure  to  meet  safeguard  requirements  in  a  timely  manner. 
These risks all appear to be low. The MFF is properly planned 
and sequenced with regard to the associated generation plan. 
Sensitivity  analyses  of  the  MFF  indicate  that  it  is  resilient  to 
increases in capital costs, and operation and maintenance costs. 
Technical capability of the implementing agencies to implement 
the MFF in a timely manner and in full compliance with ADB’s 
safeguard policies is proven.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  India  for  the  Assam  Power  Sector  Enhancement 
Investment Program. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (the TA) for 
capacity  development  of  the  Assam  power  sector  utilities,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the 
proposed MFF, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  India’s economy has grown by 8% per annum in recent years, and faces rapidly growing 
energy needs. Addressing the energy challenge is essential for fostering sustainable economic 
growth and reducing poverty. Taking into account India’s energy security concerns, in 2006 the 
Government of India (the Government) developed the Integrated Energy Policy1 to ensure 
adequate  and  reliable  energy  supplies  in  a  technically  efficient,  economically  viable,  and 
environmentally sustainable manner. Specific measures include continuing related power sector 
reforms,  e.g.,  reducing  technical  and  commercial  losses  of  the  state  transmission  and 
distribution (T&D) utilities and other restructuring efforts.   
 
3.  Given the sub-optimal performance of state electricity boards and their negative impact 
on efficient and effective delivery of power services to consumers, the Government adopted a 
program  of  unbundling  and  financial  restructuring  of  the  boards  in  the  late  1990s.  An 
independent central regulatory body was established, and the formation of state regulatory 
bodies was made mandatory. The Electricity Act (2003) was intended to improve sector through 
continued institutional restructuring and improved management of sector entities to ensure  
long-term sustainability. Compulsory metering, open access to transmission systems, facilitation 
of power trading, and tariff rationalization were initiated. Separation of transmission from the 
trading  function  was  made  obligatory.  Most  states  have  now  segregated  generation, 
transmission, and distribution functions. The Central Electricity Regulatory Commission and 
state electricity regulatory commissions have prescribed detailed tariff methodologies.  
 
4.  At state level, the government of Assam (GOA) introduced the power sector reform 
policy, Power Policy Statement 2003, aiming to (i) achieve commercial efficiency and financial 
viability of the power sector so that it does not require Assam’s financial resources, which are 
needed for socioeconomic development; (ii) improve delivery of services and cost-effectiveness 
through technical, managerial, and administrative restructuring of power utilities; (iii) increase 
the operating efficiency of all the power utilities through competition, managerial autonomy, and 
higher accountability; and (iv) create an environment that attracts private capital, both domestic 
and foreign, to supplement public sector investment. Appendix 2 provides an assessment of the 
Assam power sector.  
 
5.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)-supported  Assam  Power  Sector  Development 
Program (APSDP) provided assistance for sector reform in the state.2  The APSDP program

2.  Access to Power and Poverty Reduction  
9.  Inaccessibility to power due to distribution network constraints is a major impediment to 
Assam's  economic  growth.  The  lack  of  sufficient  and  reliable  power  is  eroding  the 
competitiveness of the state’s manufacturing and agriculture industries, impacting food security, 
and  preventing  the  state  from  accessing  industrial  and  commercial  investments.  Improved 
power supply at a reasonable cost is, therefore, essential to boost the state economy and lead 
to overall poverty reduction. More importantly, access to power directly addresses poverty 
reduction  for  households.  Per  capita  annual  electricity  consumption  for  Assam  is  170  
kilowatt-hours, only 27% of the national average. Per capita income in the state is $355, less 
than two thirds of the national average. A very high proportion of the population is in rural (89%) 
and  approximately  30%  of  households  are  living  below  the  poverty  line,  compared  to  the 
national average of 26%. Access to electricity in rural areas is crucial for human development. 
GOA, therefore, is highly committed to promoting rural electrification.  
 
10.  GOA has a target of 100% village electrification by 2010, and 100% electricity access to 
households by 2012. Under the APSDP, village electrification improved from 58% in 2003 to 
77% in 2008, and household electrification from 17% in 2003 to 22% in 2008. Therefore, new 
investments in distribution must be targeted to expand the rural distribution system. In addition, 
2,145 remote villages in Assam cannot be electrified through the grid. GOA has a strategy to 
electrify these villages by installing off-grid generation including renewable and conventional 
energy.   
3.  Transmission and Distribution Loss Reduction   
11.  One of the major outcomes of the APSDP was significant aggregate technical and 
commercial (ATC) loss reduction from 42.5% in 2003 to 35.0% in 2008. Transmission loss was 
reduced  from  9.0%  to  6.0%,  and  distribution  technical  loss  from  18.0%  to  12.5%;  both 
contributed to reducing annual greenhouse gas emissions by 0.48 million tons carbon dioxide  
(t-CO ) equivalent. However, current ATC loss is still higher than the national average of 28%. 
2
Energy efficiency must be enhanced if the Government's target of 15% ATC loss is to be met.  
 
12.  The distribution network in Assam is characterized by overloaded transformers and long 
distribution feeders, thereby increasing distribution losses to 55%–60% in some areas. The 
challenge for the T&D systems is the inadequate infrastructure and capabilities to accurately 
measure and monitor losses at each point. Furthermore, while many distribution transformers 
are metered, micro energy accounting is not possible because of the lack of consumer indexing 
and linkage with the distribution transformers. Under the APSDP, 370,000 units of intelligent 
and downloadable meters with tamper-proof boxes were installed across the state. However, 
the magnitude of the impact of such meter replacement has been limited as meter reading is still 
undertaken manually. Also, certain special features of these meters that can reduce human 
interference  in  meter  reading  have  not  been  fully  activated  because  of  the  absence  of 
information technology systems in distribution utilities. Addressing such capacity and training 
requirements in distribution utilities will have a significant impact on commercial loss reduction. 
 
4.  Sector and Corporate Governance    
13.  Cognizant of weak sector and corporate governance, GOA initiated power sector reform 
in 2001 in tandem with the APSDP. This resulted in tangible outcomes, i.e., (i) enhanced legal, 
policy, and regulatory framework; and (ii) unbundling of ASEB.

14.  Legal, Policy, and Regulatory Framework. Throughout the reform process, AERC, an 
independent state regulatory agency formed in 2001, has adopted a realistic and supportive 
position through its regulatory initiatives, e.g., (i) notification of the terms and conditions of the 
tariff in 2005, (ii) issuance of regularly updated tariff orders for the utilities attempting to focus on 
cost-recovery aspects, and (iii) notification of standards of performance for T&D licensees in 
2004. In 2009, AERC initiated multiyear tariff proceedings to enhance efficiency improvements 
and predictability in cost and tariff setting.  
 
15.  Unbundling of Assam State Electricity Board. In 2002, ASEB, under the Companies 
Act (1956), incorporated the successor entities: APGCL, AEGCL, and three distribution utilities. 
Through the transfer scheme, the existing assets of generation, transmission, and distribution 
were transferred to these utilities. ASEB remains active as a coordinating agency. Despite the 
physical  unbundling,  institutional,  managerial,  and  financial  sustainability  is  undermined  by 
limited corporate governance of the successor entities (Figure 1). Due to this constraint, ASEB 
is  responsible  for  centralized  corporate  strategy,  and  financial  and  human  resource 
management.  Capacity  development  is  required  for  the  unbundled  structure  to  be  fully 
operationalized.

III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM  
 
27.  The Investment Program will directly address sector issues based on the achievement of 
the APSDP, which has successfully created the enabling environment leading to inclusive 
economic  growth  through  power  sector  reforms  and  physical  capacity  expansion.  The 
Investment Program is a logical extension of the APSDP with further strengthening of the T&D 
system and enhancement of institutional capacity. It will require 5 years for full implementation, 
and will require flexibility in project selection to achieve overall objectives and mitigate risk. An 
MFF is particularly well suited for the Investment Program because (i) its aim is to support 
GOA’s long-term objectives, as stated in the T&D road map; (ii) the performance of ongoing 
projects under the MFF can guide the provision of subsequent loans, thereby offering proper 
incentives  for  implementation;  and  (iii)  an  MFF  can  offer  the  flexibility  required  for  the 
Investment Program to support the participation of utilities at different stages of readiness.   
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
28.  The impact of the Investment Program will be a sustainable state power sector with 
increased T&D capacity to support inclusive economic growth. The outcome will be enhanced 
quality and expanded service delivery of electricity through improved technical, commercial, and 
financial performance and capability of power utilities. 
 
B.  Outputs

transmission  lines,  transformation  capacities,  and  a  communication  system. 
Transmission lines will be expanded by 365 kilometers (km) at 220 kV and  
242 km at 132 kV. Construction of 3 new 220/132 kV substations and 11 new 
132/33  kV  substations  is  included.  The  distribution  component  includes 
construction  of  new  substations,  augmentation  of  existing  substations,  and 
addition of new distribution lines. About 20 new distribution substations will be 
constructed and 10 existing substations will be augmented.

C.  Technical Justification and Eligibility Criteria 
30.  Transmission components form part of AEGCL’s least-cost expansion plan. Its planning 
process uses investment signals provided through the national demand forecast produced by 
the Central Electricity Authority (CEA), and state energy and demand forecasts produced with 
the assistance of LAEDCL. Distribution components were modeled and analyzed using power 
systems analysis software. Best practice design standards and construction techniques will be 
applied to all investments.   
 
31.  The following criteria will be used to select projects: 
 
(i)  All projects should be economically and financially viable. 
(ii)  Project  designs  will  be  consistent  with  overall  least-cost  expansion  plans; 
designed on a least-cost basis; and reflect “best practice” design, construction, 
and operation and maintenance features. Subprojects will display performance-
based design consistent with international benchmarks for system efficiency and 
operating risk.

(iii)  Project  designs  will  be  consistent  with  the  environmental  management  plan 
(EMP), resettlement framework, and indigenous people development framework 
(IPDF).  Land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plans  and  indigenous  people 
development plans (based on the agreed IPDF and the resettlement framework) 
will  be  prepared  as  necessary  for  additional  projects  before  ADB  approves

(iv)  All  projects  require  environmental  assessments  in  accordance  with  ADB’s

D.  Special Features 
32.   Poverty  Reduction  through  Public–Private  Partnership.  The  SPPS  program  in 
Assam is based on an input-based franchisee model concept where the distribution licensee is 
responsible for providing power at a bulk supply point and the franchisee is responsible for 
billing and collection from consumers (Appendix 6). The franchisee retains a pre-set margin and 
passes  on the  remaining  collection  to  LAEDCL.  Based on  the success  demonstrated,  the 
franchisee program would be expanded to double consumer coverage through (i) physical 
investment, i.e., provision of better last-mile infrastructure by LAEDCL that could reduce losses 
and improve efficiency; and (ii) nonphysical investment, i.e., capacity development programs to 
franchisees and LAEDCL to enhance management practices. In addition, further empowerment 
to franchises will be explored by feasibility studies and development of a second generation 
distribution franchisee model with (i) more responsibilities for downstream distribution-related 
activities,  e.g.,  capital  investment,  and  expanded  operation  and  maintenance  activities;  
(ii) expansion of service in urban and larger areas; and (iii) development of risk-sharing models.  
   
33.  Off-Grid Rural Electrification mainly with Renewable Energy. Similar to the SPPS 
program  for  grid-connected  villages,  the  model  for  off-grid  rural  electrification  mainly  with 
renewable energy will be developed under the TA. The Assam Energy Development Agency, 
the nodal agency for renewable energy development, identified 2,000 villages suitable for solar 
photovoltaic  power  generation  in  remote  villages.  GOA  has  identified  90  potential  
mini-hydropower sites with total capacity of 148.5 MW and ratified the Small Hydro Power Policy 
in 2007 defining the project formulation structure where private sector groups will be selected 
through competitive bidding processes. The TA will develop pilot-testing projects of renewable 
energy, e.g., mini-hydropower, solar, and biomass; and structure the relevant operating model.   
 
34.  Strategic System Loss Reduction Program. Cognizant that the ad-hoc measures for 
technical and commercial loss reduction have been not effective, a strategic approach with 
advanced information technology and communication systems will be undertaken by combining 
physical  and  nonphysical  investment  in  tandem  with  the  national  Government’s  planed 
Restructured Accelerated Power Development and Reforms Programme initiative. To pinpoint 
the  causes  of  system  loss  at  each  location,  an  information  technology-based  integrated 
approach will be used to establish baseline data and information technology applications for 
energy  accounting  and  auditing.  Then,  an  optimal  solution,  e.g.,  system  improvement, 
strengthening, and augmentation of the distribution infrastructure, will be conducted at each 
point.

2.  Financial Sustainability: Past Performance and Projections 
 
58.  In the early 1990s, ASEB faced negative net worth, due to increases in T&D losses, 
power shortages, and inadequate quality of power supply. ASEB had a high debt-equity ratio

utilities to achieve a financial turnaround. As the result of the FRP, ASEB reduced financial 
losses  by  82.5%  from  Rs10.9  billion  in  2005  to  Rs0.9  billion  in  2008.  The  financial 
improvements are demonstrated by better actual results compared with those forecast in 2003 
for the APSDP. The debt to debt-plus-equity ratio declined from 77% in 2005 to 44% in 2008. 
Detailed analysis of sector performance is presented in Appendix 13.

3.  Financial Analysis 
61.  A financial evaluation of the transmission projects under tranche 1 was carried out in 
2009 prices. The project cost estimates and financial projections were converted into real terms 
by adjusting for the projected effects of domestic inflation. Project revenues are based on the 
methodology applied by AERC, which is expected to be in line with the recently published 2009 
Central Electricity Regulatory Commission tariff regulations.  
 
62.  The base case financial internal rate of return for the transmission projects is 7.41%, 
compared with the weighted average cost of capital of 2.10%, thus indicating financial viability. 
Sensitivity analyses showed that the results are robust to a range of project-related sensitivities 
covering increases in capital cost, operation and maintenance costs, and project implementation 
delays. A summary of the financial analysis is in Appendix 14.  
 
4.  Economic Analysis 
63.  Economic analysis was undertaken for the transmission projects to be financed under 
tranche 1 of the MFF. The economic internal rate of return was calculated by comparing the 
with- and without-project scenarios. Economic benefits accrue to consumers in Assam, the 
electricity utilities in Assam, and the overall economy.  
 
64.  The  benefits  from  incremental  consumption  of  power  are  valued  using  consumers’ 
willingness to pay, while the benefits from the nonincremental consumption of power are valued 
based on the resource cost saving from displaced generation sources. Initial estimates indicate 
that the transmission projects under the first tranche have an economic internal rate of return of 
16.80%.  This  shows  the  economic  viability  of  the  transmission  projects.  Robust  economic 
performance is demonstrated under a range of downside sensitivity analysis. A summary of the 
economic analysis is in Appendix 15.

12.04 ha will be private land and the remaining 12.04 ha will be government land.  
 
67.  The construction of transmission lines will not require any permanent land acquisition, 
and will only have a temporary effect on crops during construction. Nine households will lose 
land permanently; of these four scheduled tribe households will lose a strip of land, which will 
not be more than 10% of their productive assets. Adequate measures and entitlement are 
addressed  in  the  resettlement  plan  to  provide  for  their  vulnerability.  None  of  the  affected 
households are severely affected as they are not losing more than 10% of their productive 
assets. ASEB has ensured sufficient budgetary resources to cover the compensation packages 
provided in the resettlement plan. It also has ensured that scheduling tower construction and 
stringing minimizes crop disruption and is common practice. Impacts of tranche 1 and future 
tranches, if any, are expected to be minimal. Compensation packages and a short resettlement 
plan were prepared for the project components of tranche 1 (Appendix 17).  
 
68.  The Investment Program is expected to have positive impacts in terms of health and 
education conditions, and facilities are expected to improve in Assam. The average family size 
is 5.91. Electrical devices were found to be gender-related as women are generally considered 
to be more involved in household-related activities. In fact, the average number of electric lamps 
per households is 4.14 followed by 3.18 fans, 1.06 televisions, and 0.18 each of washing 
machines and water pumps. Among the households, those reporting having electricity said they 
used kerosene and/or diesel, wood, and gas as alternate energy along with electricity.  
 
69.  The  Investment  Program  is  designed  to  benefit  all  grid-connected  consumers  with 
adequate and reliable supply of electricity, to support the Government’s projections for growth in 
energy demand and its intent to make affordable grid-based electricity supply available to the 
entire population by 2012. Government policy includes support to poor households via a lifeline 
tariff  for  the  first  1  kilowatt-hour  of  consumption  per  household  per  day.  A  secure  and 
predictable electricity supply will enable social and economic benefits to materialize, as well as 
ensure improved conditions for schools, hospitals, and other social services. Improvements in 
quality and reliability of supply that will accrue from targeted investments are expected to 
improve living conditions in rural areas through the creation of job and income opportunities.  
 
C.  Environmental Aspects 
 
70.  An  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  (EARF)  was  prepared  for  the 
Investment Program, outlining the policy, procedures, and institutional requirements for the 
overall and for each tranche. ASEB is responsible for preparing the required environmental 
assessments  and  obtaining  ADB  concurrence  before  implementation.  Environmental 
assessment of the proposed investments has been and will continue to be conducted following 
ADB’s Environment Policy, the EARF, and applicable Government laws and regulations. The

21 
 
first tranche investments are classified as category B10 in accordance with ADB’s Environment 
Policy. ASEB has prepared the IEE for tranche 1. Environmental assessments will be prepared 
in due course for the remaining projects as applicable, in accordance with the EARF. The 
summary IEE for tranche 1 outlines environmental benefits and negative impacts, proposed 
mitigation measures, and the EMP. Public consultations indicate strong local support for the 
proposed investments. 
 
71.  For tranche 1, based on the environmental assessments and reconnaissance surveys, 
most  of  the  impacts  will  occur  during  construction.  The  principal  impacts  are  related  to 
acquisition of rights-of-way for transmission lines, earthmoving and initial clearing of vegetation 
for construction, and periodic clearing of vegetation during operations. These impacts will be 
mitigated  by  selective  routing  of  transmission  lines,  appropriate  erosion-control  measures, 
proper  management  of  construction-related  wastes,  and  provision  of  compensation  for 
reforestation, as necessary. No endangered, rare, or threatened species of flora or fauna have 
been  reported  at  any  project  sites.  Adequate  provisions  are  made  for  the  environmental 
mitigation and monitoring requirements and their associated costs. The project sites are mostly 
on  government-owned  land.  The  land  acquired  for  new  substations  is  mostly  uninhabited, 
unused,  and  outside  towns  and  villages.  Mitigation  measures  related  to  construction  and 
specified in the EMP will be incorporated into civil works contracts. Although the contractors will 
have primary responsibility for implementation of mitigation measures during construction, the 
relevant implementing agency will be responsible for overall implementation of site-specific 
EMPs. 
 
D.  Benefits and Beneficiaries 
72.  Overall the Investment Program will contribute to economic development of the state of 
Assam on several fronts. The first group of beneficiaries will be local electricity consumers, 
including about 1 million electrified households; small- and medium-sized businesses, e.g., silk 
factories; hospitals; and schools. As the second group of beneficiaries, all the existing electric 
consumers including domestic users (51%), commercial users (10%), industrial users (27%),  
agricultural users (2%), and others (10% will benefit from enhanced power operations. Through 
the  distribution  franchisee  component,  720  entrepreneurs  are  expected  to  expand  their 
operations with at least 1,500 employees.  
73.  In  addition,  construction  of  infrastructure  and  installation  of  information  and 
communication technologies are expected to create at least 500 jobs. The renewable energy 
development component will provide benefits for 2,100 villages with off-grid renewable energy in 
the long term. With 89% of Assam’s population living in rural areas, and approximately 60% of 
households living below the poverty line, the rural electrification component will have a direct 
benefit for the poor.11 The Investment Program will rationalize tariffs as well as improve the state 
power sector’s financial viability.

E.  Potential Risks 
 
74.  The key broad assumptions are (i) macroeconomic growth will remain stable; (ii) GOA 
will  remain  committed  to  further  power  sector  reforms  and  institutional  improvement;  and  
(iii)  GOA  will  execute  its  investment  plan,  successfully  combining  physical  infrastructure 
investments with nonphysical investments in capacity development to maintain a sustainable 
power sector. Broad risks include a slowdown in the depth and pace of policy and sector 
reforms. 
 
75.  These risks can be mitigated through political commitment, concerted action, and sound 
supervision. GOA is fully committed to expanding its power supply and continuing with sector 
reforms, including further tariff reform, improved corporate governance, institutional change, and 
increased private sector participation. The state is closely following the execution of the long- 
and medium-term plans for the sector, and recognizes that capacity development is a major part 
of the process. The proposed interventions will help address these issues at two separate 
levels—state and project. The themes covered are broad (planning and policy formulation) and 
specific  (due  diligence,  project  preparation,  implementation,  evaluation,  monitoring,  and 
reporting for results). Good governance and fiduciary controls are recognized as important, 
along with measures to ensure transparency and efficiency.  
 
76.  Specific project-related assumptions are (i) proper operation and maintenance of the 
installations will be carried out according to standard requirements, (ii) adequate competent staff 
are available in the companies, (iii) load growth is as projected, (iv) regulatory mechanisms and 
interventions  are  consistent,  and  (v)  the  capacity  development  program  is  successfully 
implemented. Specific project-related risks include, (i) limited capacity and coordination of ASEB 
and implementing agencies to implement projects, and (ii) limited capacity of power generation 
plants not financed by ADB, that are not commissioned in a timely manner. These risks can be 
mitigated  through  the  capacity  development  TA  and  close-coordination  with  developers  of 
associated facilities. Overall, the integrated benefits and impact are expected to outweigh the 
costs, given the likelihood of the risks occurring.

POWER SECTOR ASSESSMENT 
   
A.  Assam Power Sector Reform  
  1.  Reorganization of Assam State Electricity Board 
 
1.  Unbundling  of  Assam  State  Electricity  Board.  To  encourage  efficiency,  improve 
service  quality,  and  increase  management  accountability,  the  state  government  of  Assam 
(GOA) unbundled the Assam State Electricity Board (ASEB) into five companies: Assam Power 
Generation Corporation Limited (APGCL); Assam Electricity Grid Corporation Limited (AEGCL); 
and  three  distribution  companies:  Central  Assam  Electricity  Distribution  Company  Limited 
(CAEDCL),  Lower  Assam  Electricity  Distribution  Company  Limited  (LAEDCL),  and  Upper 
Assam  Electricity  Distribution  Company  Limited  (UAEDCL).  ASEB  remains  active  as  the 
coordinating agency. The statutory transfer scheme was approved on 10 December 2004.  
 
2.  Transfer of Assets, Liabilities, and Personnel. Within a 6-month provisional period 
ending  on  31  May  2005,  GOA  completed  the  transfer  of  assets,  liabilities,  and  personnel 
(provisionally assigned on as-is where-is basis with subsequent representation mediated by a 
GOA committee), and business arrangements to the successor companies so they could be 
independent and operating fully.  
 
3.  Governance  and  Industry  Structure.  ASEB  and  its  successor  companies  filed 
intercompany contracts with Assam Electricity Regulatory Commission (AERC), including power 
purchase  agreements,  transmission  service  agreements,  and  bulk  supply  agreements  with 
ASEB retaining the bulk purchaser function during the transition period. Independent managing 
directors and a board of directors are responsible for the operation of each company. 
 
  2.  Regulatory Framework and Tariff Reforms 
 
4.  Capacity Building and Staffing of AERC. In February 2005, GOA decided to expand 
AERC from a one-member commission to a multimember commission with a chairperson and 
two  members.  The  commission  structure  has  been  retained  along  with  secretarial  and 
administrative staff. 
 
5.  Regulatory Rules and Standards. In accordance with the Electricity Act (2003), AERC 
and  GOA  have  progressively  framed  a  number  of  codes,  rules,  and  standards  governing  
tariff-setting, licensing, long-term sector planning, a nondiscretionary business environment, and 
adjudication of disputes. Principal Regulations were notified by May 2005, with progressive 
amendments issued consistent with national policies and guidelines and Appellate Tribunal 
Order. 
 
6.  Tariff Rationalization. AERC has been rationalizing the tariffs since the first tariff order 
in April 2003. For the three subsequent tariff orders for the utilities since FY2006 onward, AERC 
adopted a performance-based regulation with return on equity linked to utility performance  
(7% for LAEDCL, 14% for AEGCL in 2008). The cost coverage (ratio of tariff to cost) at LAEDCL 
level as per AERC tariff order 2007/08 is expected to reach 88% from own consumers. On the 
issue of multiyear tariffs and a 3-year control period starting 2007, AERC after considering the 
unavailability  of  reliable  utility  data,  restructuring  impacts,  and  utility  preparedness  for  a 
multiyear tariff adopted a cautious approach of examining and approving costs on a single-year 
basis.

B.  Physical Power Sector Overview 
7.  Generation. Assam experienced increased peak power shortages over the entire 10th 
five year Plan period (1% at end of the 9th Plan to 8.4% in 2007/08). This has had a severe 
impact since demand in Assam has increased at a consistent pace from 688 megawatts (MW) 
in FY2002 to 848 MW in FY2008, Generation from APGCL accounted for 45% of Assam’s total 
power availability of 1,960 gigawatt-hours in the first half of 2008. Only 766 MW were available 
to respond to the peak power demand of 848 MW in 2008. This is expected to be addressed 
with adequate generation capacity being developed for Assam.  
8.  Transmission. Since 2002, AEGCL has been expanding capacity and currently has 38 
substations and 4,189 circuit-kilometers of transmission lines (voltage ranging from 66 kV to  
220 kV). In FY2008, the transmission network was able to meet a maximum demand of 766 MW 
(90% of the maximum demand) of Assam and transmitted 4,079 gigawatt hours (92% of energy 
requirement).  The  transmission  capacity  is  inadequate  to  serve  peak  demand,  which  is 
expected to grow at an annual rate of 14.8% to reach 1,883 MW in 2014 as per the 17th Electric 
Power Survey of the CEA.  
9.  Distribution.  The  Assam  distribution  sector  intends  to  meet  the  national  target  of 
electrification for all by 2012 as well as 100% household electrification by 2012. Despite some 
improvement during the Assam Power Sector Development Program, significant improvements 
are needed for (i) reducing losses in excess of 30% (preferably to 15%, as envisaged in the the 
Government policy directive), (ii) increasing inadequate transformation capacity at 11 kV, (iii) 
improving consumer metering, and (iv) enhancing billing efficiencies. Village electrification was 
only 77% in 2008. New investments need to be targeted to improve the quality of supply and 
reduce  long  low  voltage  circuits  and  distribution  transformer  overloading  through  (i) 
transformation capacity;  (ii) sub transmission network capacity (33 kV and 11 kV) addition; (iii) 
introduction of high voltage distribution system and advanced technology-based transformers, 
e.g., amorphous core transformers in the distribution network; (iv) introduction of smaller-rating 
transformers at intermittent places in long-lines; and (v) introduction of aerial bunched cables in 
theft-prone  areas.

(Power for All at Sualkuchi Village in Assam) 
 
 
1.  The single point power supply (SPPS) program in Assam is an input-based franchisee 
model concept where the distribution licensee, Lower Assam Electricity Distribution Company 
Limited (LAEDCL) is responsible for providing power at a bulk supply point and the franchisee is 
responsible for the billing and collection from consumers. The community-based private sector 
and nongovernment organizations selected through competitive bidding process buy electricity 
from LAEDCL. The franchisee retains a pre-set margin and passes on the remaining collection 
to LAEDCL. With 720 franchisees, the SPPS program has enhanced power sector governance 
with more participation, competition, and transparency; and improved sector financial viability. 
Under the 2003 Assam Power Sector Development Program, power supply in Sualkuchi was 
expanded in a reliable manner by the SPPS program, enabling more electrification of village 
households  and  increased  consumption.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  studied  the 
impact on small silk factories, a hospital, and a school through a series of field visits and 
interviews with village residents. This appendix summarizes the outcome of a field case study 
by  ADB  conducted  from  January  to  March  2009  to  assess  the  example  of  direct  linkage 
between reliable electricity supply and poverty reduction.  
 
2.  Power for Silk Factories. ADB visited one of the oldest small silk Sualkuchi factories—
Braza Silk Factory—in Sualkuchi village, where approximately 40 women employees work. 
While talking to the female workers and management, the SPPS scheme was noted to be a 
crucial role element in for the overall development and progress of the factory. People are of the 
opinion that, prior to the SPPS scheme, the supply of electricity was not adequate. Female 
workers were limited to 6 hours of work because of the limited electricity supply.

FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT 
1.  A  financial  management  assessment  of  the  Executing  Agency,  the  Assam  State 
Electricity  Board  (ASEB)  and  implementing  agencies:  Assam  Electricity  Grid  Corporation 
Limited (AEGCL) and Lower Assam Electricity Distribution Company Limited was undertaken to 
assess their ability to undertake and fulfill fiduciary requirements for the project components of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The assessment was in accordance with ADB guidelines 
using the financial management assessment questionnaire and field interviews, and was  in 
accordance with the guidelines of ADB’s Financial Management and Analysis of Projects.  
 
2.  Prior to 2003, ASEB was responsible for carrying out all the financial management-
related functions for the unbundled entity. ASEB prepared its accounts as per the old Electricity 
(Supply) Annual Accounts Rules (1985). Specific financial management-related gaps in training, 
processes, and systems resulted in deficiencies in the cash management function at ASEB. 
This,  in  some  part,  resulted  in  repeated  defaults  on  payment  to  suppliers  and  over  time 
contributed to a worsening of the financial situation in ASEB as cross-subsidizing consumers, 
e.g., tea gardens and industries, moved out of the distribution network because of unreliable 
power  supply.  This  eventually  resulted  in  reduced  cost  coverage  for  ASEB,  coupled  with 
unsustainable debt and negative net worth. 
 
3.  Under  the  ADB-supported  Assam  Power  Sector  Development  Program  (APSDP), 
commencing in 2003, structural reforms were initiated to improve the operating and financial 
performance of ASEB. The state government of Assam (GOA) unbundled ASEB into Assam 
Power Generation Corporation Limited (APGCL); AEGCL; and three distribution companies in 
the lower, central, and upper areas of Assam. ASEB remains active as the coordinating agency.  
 
4.  GOA also implemented a financial restructuring plan (FRP) for debt restructuring and 
provided transitional support to enable the newly formed utilities to commence operations with a 
clean balance sheet without the burden of past ASEB liabilities. Each of the newly formed 
generation, transmission, and distribution companies is required to comply with the accounting 
and reporting standards prescribed by the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India and the 
Companies Act (1956).  
 
5.  The APSDP resulted in several accomplishments in the area of financial management. 
The newly formed companies have introduced accounting policies as per statutory reporting 
requirements and conducted statutory audits of their financial statements as per Institute of 
Chartered Accountants of India guidelines, using independent auditors. No major accountability 
issues  were  identified  in  the  independent  audit  report  for  2005–2007.  Audited  financial 
statements for 2007/08 are expected to be released shortly. As required under the APSDP loan 
covenant,  audited  project  accounts  and  audited  financial  statements  of  ASEB  have  been 
regularly submitted, though with some delays.  
 
6.  Despite noticeable improvements, certain constraints have been identified with respect 
to carrying out the financial management function. These constraints need to be addressed 
under the sector road map and policy dialogue for the proposed multitranche financing facility. 
The newly formed generation, transmission, and distribution companies continue to be partially 
autonomous with regard to financial management and operate under a centralized cash flow 
mechanism where all revenue collections from distribution utilities are routed to ASEB and cash 
requirements to meet expenses in each company are drawn from ASEB on a need basis.

SUMMARY OF SHORT RESETTLEMENT PLAN 
 
1.  The proposed multitranche financing facility (MFF) objective is to attain inclusive economic 
growth  sector  development  in  Assam  through  (i)  transmission  capacity  expansion,  (ii) 
transmission  and  distribution  loss  reduction,  (iii)  access  to  power,  and  (iv)  distribution 
franchising. The Government of Assam and the Assam State Electricity Board (ASEB) will be 
the  executing  agencies.  This  is  a  short  resettlement  plan  prepared  for  the  tranche  1 
components, which include construction of substations, transmission lines, and augmentation 
and/or expansion of existing substations. 
 
A.  Impact on Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
2.  An assessment of land acquisition and resettlement was carried out for the tranche 1 
projects. They have minimized resettlement by adopting adequate engineering solutions in their 
design  through  proper  involvement  of  all stakeholders.  No  relocation  is  anticipated  as  the 
projects  include  transmission  components  that  entail  minimal  land  acquisition.  Of  the  
6 substations, 3 will be constructed on government land, which is free from any use. Two 
substations  are  proposed  to  be  constructed  on  barren  land  of  the  tea  garden  owner  and 
company, and the remaining 1 substation will require private land acquisition. Approximately 
24.09 hectares (ha) will be required for the substations: 12.04 ha of private land and 12.04 ha of 
government land. The construction of transmission lines (262 kilometers) will not require any 
permanent land acquisition, but will have a temporary effect on crops during construction. Of the 
9 households affected, 4 are scheduled tribe households that will lose a strip of land of not more 
than 10% of their productive assets. Adequate measures and entitlement are addressed in the 
resettlement plan. Of the 22 affected people, 12 are male and 10 are female; 6 households 
affected are vulnerable. None of the affected households are severely affected as they are not 
losing more than 10% of their productive assets. The summary of impacts are given in Table

C.  Institutional Arrangements 
 
4.  The government of Assam and ASEB will function as the executing agencies for the 
MFF.  Assam  Power  Generation  Corporation  Limited  will  be  the  Implementing  Agency 
responsible for day-to-day implementation of projects for transmission systems, and Lower 
Assam Electricity Distribution Company Limited the Implementing Agency for distribution system 
projects. ASEB, already has a functioning project management unit (PMU), which implemented 
the  ADB-financed  Assam  Power  Sector  Development  Program.  It  is  responsible  for  the 
preparatory work for the MFF. An environment and social management unit (ESMU) will be set 
up within the PMU along with other engineering units to address environmental and social 
issues that arise. The ESMU will be headed by an environment specialist and resettlement 
specialist, assisted by one environment and one social development–resettlement specialist 
who will be responsible for field activities. The PMU will be responsible for overall coordination, 
preparation, planning, implementation, and financing. The ASEB will ensure that key institutions 
including  local  governments  are  involved  in  resettlement  plan  preparation,  updating,  and 
implementation.

D.  Consultation, Disclosure, and Grievance 
 
5.  Consultations were carried out with various government officials and local communities 
concerned as part of the social and resettlement study to gather their views on the Tranche 1 
projects.  All  affected  people  were  consulted  on  a  one-to-one  basis  through  questionnaire 
surveys for the project activities. Additionally, focus group discussions were carried out at all the 
proposed substation sites and along the transmission corridors. Local residents expressed their 
cooperation for smooth project implementation. The consultation process will be continued 
during the entire project cycle. The resettlement plan for tranche 1 was translated to Assamese 
local language, and was made available at relevant government offices, ASEB project site 
offices, and the PMU. The resettlement plan for the tranche 1 projects was disclosed before the 
first ADB management review meeting and placed on the ADB website. An efficient grievance 
redress  mechanism  will  be  developed  to  assist  affected  people  resolve  their  queries  and 
complaints.  Each  resettlement  plan  will  detail  specific  grievance  redress  mechanisms. 
Grievances of affected people will first be brought to the attention to the site office of the 
concerned implementing agency. Grievances not redressed by the implementing agency field 
staff  will  be  brought  to  the  grievance  redress  committee.  The  committee  will  have 
representatives from affected people, PMU, implementing agency, ESMU, field staff, district 
magistrate and/or commissioner, local administration, revenue authority, and local community. 
 
E.  Resettlement Budget and Fund Flow Mechanism 
 
6.  The  resettlement  cost  estimate  for  the  first  trance  projects  includes  eligible 
compensation, resettlement assistance, and support cost for resettlement plan implementation. 
These are part of the overall project cost. The total land acquisition and resettlement cost is 
estimated to be Rs17.89 million. Land acquisition and resettlement costs will be considered as 
an integral component of subproject costs. ASEB will make the funds available in its annual 
budget for the disbursement of compensation and assistance. 
 
F.  Implementation Schedule, Monitoring, and Evaluation 
 
7.  All land acquisition, resettlement, and compensation will be completed before the start of 
civil works. All land required will be provided free of encumbrances to the contractor prior to 
handing  over  the  project  sites  and  the  start  of  civil  works.  Internal  monitoring  will  be  the 
responsibility of the PMU of ASEB. External monitoring will be done by an external monitoring 
consultant.
